So said  Edwin Hautus <ehautus@...>  on  2002-12-31
--------------------

>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
>> So said  Edwin Hautus <ehautus@x...>  on  12/30/2002
>> --------------------
>> 
>> >I have just started to explore JUnit. So far I have used Ant
>> >to write test-scipts (based on the command line interface for my 
>> >application). Of course, these test are not really unit tests, but 
>> >application tests. Nevertheless, they are very useful.
>> >
>> >My question is therefore, does anybody have any ideas about 
>> >converting already existing Ant based tests to JUnit?
>> >
>> >Basically, I am using some Ant functionality to copy directories 
>> >files, call javac, and define some properties. I wouldn't like to 
>> >rewrite all the scripts in Java, but calling Ant from JUnit turns 
>out 
>> >to be a bit ackward as well. Are there any other tools I might 
>want 
>> >to use?
>> 
>> Well, JUnit tests are written in Java, but you don't want to rewrite
>> your tests in Java, so why do you want to use JUnit? I would say,
>> "Don't bother."
>> 
>> What pain do you feel by not having these tests written in Java?
>> 
>
>I don't care if they are not written in Java, but I thought it would 
>be nicer to have all tests under a single test system. So I also 
>looked at calling ANT from JUnit, but didn't find an easy way to do 
>that.

Call your ANT target your "test system" and go with that. If you begin
to feel stronger pain later, then reconsider. By then, you might have
learned something useful. We might all have! :)

Good luck.
